user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_close:
```c
int lfs_dir_close(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_close(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)dir);

    err = lfs_dir_close_(lfs, dir);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_close -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_close:
static int lfs_dir_close_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    // remove from list of mdirs
    lfs_mlist_remove(lfs, (struct lfs_mlist *)dir);

    return 0;
}
...
static void lfs_mlist_remove(lfs_t *lfs, struct lfs_mlist *mlist) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &lfs->mlist; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == mlist) {
            *p = (*p)->next;
            break;
        }
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No uses of the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in the provided code fragments. Examination of all provided functions shows only pointer list manipulation and macro calls:

- lfs_dir_close: calls LFS_LOCK, LFS_TRACE, lfs_dir_close_, and LFS_UNLOCK. None of these calls, as shown, invoke any string.h APIs.
- lfs_dir_close_: calls lfs_mlist_remove to unlink a node; no string operations.
- lfs_mlist_remove: iterates and updates pointer links only; no string operations.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation under Rule 21.17.

Note: The macros LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, and LFS_TRACE are invoked here but their definitions were not provided. If their expansions (elsewhere in the codebase) use any of the string.h functions, those macro definitions should be inspected for potential out-of-bounds accesses. Based on the supplied code alone, no further investigation is required for Rule 21.17.
